text_en: Over the past two weeks, you felt unmotivated or lost interest in almost everything.
Over the past two weeks, you felt low, depressed, or hopeless.
Over the past two weeks, you had trouble falling asleep, staying asleep, or you slept far more than usual.
Over the past two weeks, you felt exhausted or had very little energy.
Over the past two weeks, your appetite noticeably decreased, or you ate much more than usual.
Over the past two weeks, you felt you were not good enough, a failure, or that you let yourself or your family down.
Over the past two weeks, you struggled to concentrate (e.g., reading, working, watching videos).
Over the past two weeks, you moved or spoke so slowly that others noticed; or you felt unusually restless and fidgety.
Over the past two weeks, you had thoughts of disappearing or not wanting to live, or thoughts of harming yourself.
Over the past two weeks, you felt tense, anxious, or on edge.
Over the past two weeks, once worrying started, it was hard to stop or control.
Over the past two weeks, you worried too much about many different things.
Over the past two weeks, you found it hard to relax.
Over the past two weeks, you felt so restless that sitting still was difficult.
Over the past two weeks, you became easily annoyed or irritable.
Over the past two weeks, you felt afraid that something terrible might happen.
Over the past month, you felt unable to control important things in your life.
Over the past month, you felt confident in your ability to handle your personal problems.
Over the past month, you felt things were moving in the direction you wanted.
Over the past month, you felt problems were piling up and hard to overcome.
Over the past month, you were able to adapt to changes in your life.
Over the past month, you were able to handle unexpected events that came your way.
Over the past month, you tried to look for the positive or interesting side of situations.
Over the past month, coping with stress helped you become stronger.
Over the past month, you bounced back fairly quickly after setbacks.
Over the past month, even with obstacles, you kept moving forward and worked toward your goals.
Over the past month, under pressure, you stayed focused and could think clearly.
Over the past month, failure did not knock you down easily.
Over the past month, you saw yourself as a strong person.
Over the past month, you were able to manage uncomfortable emotions well.
Growing up, my parents set very high standards for me.
Doing things in an organized and systematic way matters a lot to me.
Not setting the bar at the top makes me feel like I am not good enough.
I prefer an environment that is tidy and orderly.
I deliberately try to make my way of doing things more organized.
When I fail at work or study, I take it as proof that I am a failure as a person.
My parents wanted me to be outstanding in every area.
Compared with most people, I set higher goals for myself.
Seeing others outperform me at work or study makes me strongly doubt myself.
A partial setback makes me feel like the whole thing is a failure.
Even when I do something carefully, I often doubt it and feel the need to check again.
I hate not doing things as well as they can be done.
I hold extremely high goals for myself.
My parents expected me to perform exceptionally well.
I worry that making mistakes will cause others to look down on me.
Not doing as well as others makes me feel inadequate.
I often feel others can accept lower standards, while I cannot.
When I do not perform well enough, I worry about losing other people's respect.
My parents' expectations for my future were usually higher than my own.
I try hard to keep my living and working spaces neat.
I often doubt small things I have done and feel the need to re-check them.
Tidiness is extremely important to me.
I demand better results from myself in my day-to-day study or work.
I think of myself as an organized person.
Repeated checking or re-confirming often slows down my work or study.
I often take a long time to finish something until I feel fully at ease about it.
I find it difficult to meet the standards my parents set for me.
Over the past 7 days, average daily time spent on obsessive thoughts (unwanted repeated thoughts, e.g., repeatedly doubting whether you locked the door).
Over the past 7 days, how much have obsessive thoughts interfered with your social or work functioning?
Over the past 7 days, how much distress have obsessive thoughts caused you?
Over the past 7 days, how much effort did you make to resist obsessive thoughts?
Over the past 7 days, how much control did you have over obsessive thoughts?
Over the past 7 days, average daily time spent on compulsive behaviors (repetitive actions done to reduce anxiety, e.g., repeated handwashing).
Over the past 7 days, how much have compulsive behaviors interfered with your social or work functioning?
Over the past 7 days, how anxious did you become when you were prevented from performing compulsive behaviors?
Over the past 7 days, how much effort did you make to resist compulsive behaviors?
Over the past 7 days, how much control did you have over compulsive behaviors?
Overall, how much have the above emotions, stress, or compulsive habits interfered with your normal daily life (e.g., work efficiency, relationships, self-care)?
